dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a mud-streaked AIRFIELD in mist and driving RAIN A Lockheed ELECTRA sits. Sleek, twin-engine, state-of-the art, its metallic surface battered by the monsoon. Waitin PULL BACK to see... ...our VIEW down onto the landing strip is from an open- sided, thatched roof BAR high above the airfield. And peering down through the mist and rain... ...a WOMAN in grimy flight clothes gazes at the plane. Slender. Feminine. At first glance, fragile. Then the gra eyes change like the sea, as a stray thought transforms h Something fierce lives there. SUPERIMPOSE:   LAE, NEW GUINEA - 1937.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I can't talk you inta somethin' more adventurous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns. FRED NOONAN is tall and lean, ruggedly handsom in a reckless way. His flight clothes as rumpled and dirt streaked as her own. He carries his bottle of tequila, an Coke which he sets down for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adventurous? You've got the wrong girl, Mister. You should know that by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes study him.    Assessing something as he pours hi four fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually. I knew that the moment I met ol' George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sips his drink.    She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like how you don't talk about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That why I get so many chances to not do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.   Natural curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His charming smile. She's thinking more about the tequila She reaches to take his bottle and glass. Moves them to h side of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, why would a guy who needs to run the show. Pick the one girl he knew could kick his tail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.   Just her clear direct gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he knew that. First time he met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought I hated him.      He never knew I was fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 Alone by the window, he gazes at the city. A powerfully built man in a perfectly-tailored suit. The face at once strong and elegant, capable of every emotion. Yet just no there are none to be seen. Even as... ...a door OPENS. A pretty SECRETARY enters soundlessly, s respectfully. Waits, her pen suspended above her steno pa Does he know she's there? SUPERIMPOSE:   NEW YORK, LATER 1937.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning) The first time I met her she sat in that chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The secretary doesn't know whether to write that down. still with his back to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may as well write it down, Mary. Write it all down. Even the parts that are confused or graceless or boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns with a soft smile to put her at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see if I remember how to edit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles back. She likes him, as much as her level of being awed by him permits. She begins to write, as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd kept her waiting two hours. T She hated me on sight, but she hought I couldn't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His gaze drifts to a bookcase crammed with volumes. And o object, oddly out of place. A stuffed CAT, with boots and green frock coat. It wears a confident ironic smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a person who cherished her privacy and was devoting her life to social work. And there I was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile is kind.   And honestly self-mocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Self-obsessed. Wallowing in the glory of my authors and celebrity acquaintances. A vain, fast- talking, manipulator. But then I guess you know all that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up reproachfully.   Nothing of the kind, and yo know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. And the kind of man who fishes for compliments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's made her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is younger, dressed conservatively. The calm at the center of a storm. Agents, authors, couriers, peddlers co and go. But she has her legs drawn up beneath her, pourin through a small stack of volumes. As if preparing for an exam. SUPERIMPOSE:   G.P. PUTNAM'S SONS PUBLISHING CO. 1928.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiting made her furious. She undoubtedly felt I was E stablishing my dominance and importance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't look furious at all. Thumbing through WE by C CHARLES LINDBERGH. Photos of Lindy beside the Spirit of S Louis in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I hadn't given her a thought. Oblivious as usual. Which, perhaps, was even worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, SKYWARD by ADM. RICHARD BYRD. Photos of the explorer preparing for his flight over the North Pole. One of Byrd with George himself, displaying considerable gravitas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured he'd be pompous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eye travels over the stack of books. Adventurers, explorers, celebrities. On an end table, a framed photo o George with the great Lindbergh. A pretty SECRETARY comes to summon her. Amelia rises, smooths the wrinkles from her brown suit. They head down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew, of course, that he wasn't going to choose me. I had no discernible qualifications whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the door, already ajar. It says GEORGE PALMER PUTNAM on a small bronze plate. The secretary gingerly pushes it open... ...revealing George on the phone in crisp shirtsleeves an suspenders. He paces, prowls, trailing the cord behind hi negotiating non-stop even as he flips through a pile of messages. Off again, stalking the room. Dashing, electric masterful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But to be rejected by this... parasite. A man who had given up any life of his own to flutter near the famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances up, realizing for the first time that she is there. Sit, please. But she doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know whether to laugh or throw something at the jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures again, more commandingly. Sit. She doesn't move, she doesn't smile. She doesn't take her steady gaze from him. He hangs up the phone. They stare at each other for a frozen beat.   He breaks t moment with a charming smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Earhart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Putnam? GEORGE (softly) I asked you to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that the thing you did with your hand? Sadly, I don't speak dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile now only a trace.       But more genuine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A            Ah.   Well, stand if you like. melia sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm told you want to fly the Atlantic Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the 12 months since Lindbergh, 55 people in 18 planes have tried. Three planes made it. Fourteen people have died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three women died trying. Two others escaped with their lives. If you do make it, you'd be the first. Which...is the real attraction for both of us, I suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.    No smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always nice to know what the real attraction is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile.    Beginning to enjoy this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane was bought from Adm. Byrd by Amy Guest, a socialite who wanted the record for herself. Her family wouldn't tolerate the danger. She has asked for a replacement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures.   Perhaps you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who is American, educated, well- spoken, a flyer, preferably physically attractive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would that matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she wants the world to pay attention. And pretty girls command more attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that your advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. My role is selling this event to the public. There will be a contract for the girl's story with the New York Times. Also a book to be published over her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understood...?       G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all the money from these will go to Mrs. Guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the part that goes to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which will be as great as I can manage, I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said she wants a flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get your hopes up. The celebrated Wilmer Stultz will be the pilot. There'll be a male co- pilot and navigator. The woman will be purely a passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for reaction.   She keeps her mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good for your chances. Because your level of flying experience wouldn't place you anywhere near the group that would be considered for this. If the woman were to do any flying at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No punches pulled.   Not his style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would anyone want a book from a passenger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the hook is that we're making the woman the commander. The pilot will sign a contract saying he is under her direction and control. It's her ship, her flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for my chances, you said. What are my chan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The job's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blinks.   Stunned speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I chose you the moment you walked through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles his charming smile.    Several phones are RINGI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now assuming my awful manners haven't soured you on the enterprise. May I give you a lift to the station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia rises.   Is she pissed at being toyed with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a busy man, Mr. Putnam.     I can find my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look holds.   He shrugs.   You probably can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two figures on the platform.   Her train is ready to leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I honestly feel an apology is in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   What have I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mind waiting. Caught up on my reading. Knitted a sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean an apology.   For what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be pretty controlling these next few months. How you dress, move, cut your hair. Speak in public. It's all part of the package we're selling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. If you're not in there selling with me, it won't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile turns friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the star. I'm no one at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoken like a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps up onto the train. Extends her hand like a man. He shakes it firmly. The train begins to move. She watche his cheery wave as she rolls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course a gentleman. Would have paid for my ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gazing out the window as she rattles toward Boston. She looks down now to a notebook in her lap. As she flips pag we see it is a collection of hand-written POEMS and thoug She writes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Courage is the price that life exacts For granting peace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SUPERIMPOSE over her image the wall of a little girl's bedroom, filled with treasured NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS about women doctors, officials, bank presidents, women who had established themselves in positions previously thought to available only to men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soul that knows it not Knows no release From little things

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two LITTLE GIRLS, maybe 10 years old, walking in a field. Amelia and a girlfriend. They stop, hearing... The DRONING of an engine, a small red plane APPEARING abo the treetops. The pilot seeing two girls alone in the fie SWOOPS down to BUZZ them. Amelia's friend runs for her li But Amelia stands still, throws her arms WIDE, and the plane... ...DROPS lower, and LOWER, as it CLOSES straight in on th slender girl with her outstretched arms. LOUDER and FASTE as if intent on winning some impulsive duel of wills. The aircraft SCREAMS past, just above her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the little red airplane passed by, it said something to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia beams.   She fills her lungs, transported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I've ever stopped listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on her, hair and uniform whipping in the breeze. SMASH CUT TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia flying her little yellow Kinner.   Feeling the fre she thrilled to as a A child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years, 28 jobs and an unspeak- able number of crashes later, I hadn't changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She LIFTS the nose of the tiny craft.   Begins to CLIMB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I even had my own plane. Bought with my last dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the apex of her climb, she FLIPS into a breathtaking L THE LOOP, as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course in the early days of flying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...her engine SPUTTERS. Then STALLS.    The plane DIPS in TAIL-SPIN, PLUNGING downward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...crashing was so common, you almost forgot it could kill you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia STRUGGLING to start the engine, the little plane HURTLING toward earth, SPINNING as it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...until it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine COUGHS to life and at the last second she SWOO harrowingly above the ground to SOAR FREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 A small HANGAR in a lonely field.   See a group of... ...MECHANICS in their grease-stained jumpsuits. Three big guys and one little one working on an engine that's been pulled from Amelia's Kinner. When the little guy comes up for air... ...he isn't a guy at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.   I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM CHAPMAN, a handsome young man is being led down an institutional hallway and out onto the grounds of this venerable settlement house. He finds... ...Amelia sitting cross-legged on the grass. Reading to a group of CHINESE GIRLS, who hang on her every animated wo On the periphery, ADULTS sit, taking in the story. They a of various ethnicities, homeless or handicapped or immigr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two are blind. Amelia sees Sam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls, this is Mr. Samuel Chapman. Sam, say hullo to the Octopus Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Octopus Club waves to Sam.   The adults wave, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just in time. Alice has come through the Looking Glass, and things are getting, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on cue) REALLY STRANGE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pats the grass beside her.   Sam has no choice but to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Amelia and Sam walk a wooded path beside the grounds. Through the chain link fence, they watch other social wor playing with groups of children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has to be. Competition, you know. Millionaire heiresses, hot shot girl pilots. If George knew I told you, he'd have me publicly flogged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long as he could sell tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no one else knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion. She's giving me a leave of absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would think so. Your name will be in all the papers, and not just Boston. Denison House stands to come in for funding, national attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Specially if I don't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't joke about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't joking at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll make it. And then you'll have opportunities to work in aviation. Anywhere you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll have impressive credentials as a long-distance passenger. That's not exactly a career in aviation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at his eyes. I         AMELIA (CONT'D) 'm not going anywhere, social work is my life. After all the years of false starts, I found the thing I'm meant to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep walking.   She gives him time to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where does that leave us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do love to look on the dark side. Whatever did you see in a sunny character like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a sweet playful smile.   It doesn't reassur him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as if I'd been putting pressure on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What love means to you. What it requires. Is the pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Is that such a terrible problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gazes at him.   Can he even hear this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is what it's always been. The problem is me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 MOVIETONE NEWSREEL footage, accompanied by their signatur fanfare theme. Hotel conference room jammed with press. A sexy brunette in a sweater that seems to be made of strip GOLD FOIL steps to a bank of microphones. Flashes start POPPING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen of Diamonds Mabel Boll, about to become the first female to fly the Atlantic in the wake of Lindbergh's historic journey, regales an eager world press...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound switches to Mabel at the mikes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys. I'll take any questions you wanna throw my way. Except about what's behind this sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys ROAR.   Mabel keeps her smile tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story.     Behind it. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the laughter CONTINUES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he heavy door rolls OPEN. George and Amelia enter the brightly-lit hangar to see two men working on the FRIENDS a sea-plane with golden wings. Its red-orange fuselage stands beside gigantic PONTOONS, each 29 feet long. The pontoons have been opened, and the men are attaching them the plane. They turn toward us now. BILL STULTZ is short and wiry wi quick eyes. Only 28, he seems weathered by his adventures and the streaks of gray through his hair. He is not necessarily happy to see us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George had told me Stultz was Adm. Byrd's favorite pilot, fearless, gifted. He drank. But George said it never affected his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George waves as we approach.   Bill and Amelia seem locke each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he said it, I must have had a funny look. So I just said, `Yeh, I grew up around a guy like that.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, I'd like to introduce your commander, Miss Amelia Earhart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We felt `commander' was less grandiose than, say, `empress.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill doesn't smile.   The other man does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hello to Slim Gordon your navigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is shaking hands in that strong, direct way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Bill Stultz here, simply the most talented pilot working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes Bill's powerful hand. The look between them cal yet somehow intense. As if each is establishing a tone fo their relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got Byrd's pilot, we've got his plane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y ou mean the Admiral flies on those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pontoons.   She does not seem admiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, those are new, personally suggested by the old man himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill nods on that.   Sure were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, if you're forced down at sea, you can wait for a rescue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmn.   What does that do to our fuel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Costs us at least 400 gallons. Don't bother bringing clothes for Paris, we'll be lucky to hit the nearest beach in Ireland. Real lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Admiral estimates the pontoons only cut our range by 200 miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Amelia looks to Bill.   That's not really possible is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Admiral is the Admiral. He gets to estimate any damn thing he wants. All we have to do is figure out how to fly without petrol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to George with challenging eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go blaming the bookseller. He's been all through this with Mrs. Guest, but she worships the Admiral. And it's money that puts planes in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if it can keep them up there. Not that I've ever had enough to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill's small smile.   Maybe the girl's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Amelia approach a waiting motorboat, as the li of Boston glimmer across the harbor. His head is down. She's watching his profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.    I'll try keeping my mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I ought to try. Is listening to you once in awhile.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e meant that.   And she seems oddly touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful.    I could get to like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction from him. He hops into the boat. Turns, holds out his hand. She hesitates. Clearly doesn't need his hel to jump into a boat. Their eyes lock. We are watching her decide. And then... She reaches to clasp his hand.   Hops down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Simpkin. Thank you for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile) Simpkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in a book. Oh, that's right. You read the ones you publish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her smile is friendly, not flirtatious. She goes to sit i the bow. He doesn't follow. But he is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia in a flying outfit.   Hands on her hips as if posi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a Beatrix Potter story about a cat named Simpkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to see the PHOTOGRAPHER, George beside him. The are on a hotel rooftop, precariously high above Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't happy unless he had several mice, each under a different teacup. So he could never become bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Amelia's POSE looks exactly the SAME as a pho of CHARLES LINDBERGH in the photographer's hand. It is labeled `LUCKY LINDY.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THe illusion of activity was essential for him to feel at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographer now shows George ANOTHER PHOTO of Lindbe in a different pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you boys doing over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to make you look like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George studies the photo, then goes to Amelia and begins moving her body into the new pose. Tilting her head to Lindbergh's angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered.     Was I Mr. Putnam's 43rd mouse?     Or his 307th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now touching her, adjusting her coat, fluffing a bit of h hair, pulling the collar around to frame her face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he more we can make you look like a girl, the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, is it worth the effort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cocks his head, studies her.    Nah, guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wondering who should play you in the film of all this. I'm thinking Chaplin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentino's not available?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head sadly. Adjusts her collar once more. This time, his hands linger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two things. One, Chaplin can't play me because he's perfect for you. And two, you have company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances to where a WOMAN, beautiful and aristocratic, being helped onto the roof. George's face lights to see h He rushes over, sweeps her into his arms, kisses her tenderly. Amelia smiles to see this, makes her like them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia Earhart, this is Dorothy Binney Putnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women trade smiles.   They shake hands, holding eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great to meet you. George talks so much about you. (a wink) In fact, lately, you're all he does talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George steps in close, and the photographer SNAPS a three shot. And another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold those smiles for one more, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 The FRIENDSHIP bobbing on its pontoons. Bill and Slim are off-loading equipment and other gear from the plane to a TUGBOAT filled with support crew and family. The plane's engines REV in the predawn stillness. PULL BACK to see... 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 ...the yacht club dock. George and Amelia alone at the railing. She's wearing her leather flight jacket and boot They stare out at the plane, so frail and awkward. From h bag now, she pulls three ENVELOPES... Puts them in George's hand.   Straight, unblinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Popping off letters. For my dad, my mom, my sis. You know. In case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares down. Rocked by the weight of this against the simplicity of her words. The top envelope says: DEAREST DAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm honored. That you'd leave these with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else? If I do pop off, it's your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said in her sunny way. But she's not kidding.    It takes beat before he can offer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call them once you're safely on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam will handle that.   They trust him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That registers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've figured out the Simpkin thing, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. There are so few books I haven't published, it was easy to find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrix Potter, the Tailor of Gloucester. He's a cat in a green frock coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why is he you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's brilliant, charismatic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you haven't actually read it. Do you actually read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...neurotic, compulsive, manipulative. Am I getting warmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P ray I make it. Or the secret pops off with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A held look.     A friendly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.   See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off down the dock toward the Friendship. e stands watching her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia alone, leaving her hotel room in her flight jacket Locking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first hop was to Canada, to start from as close as we could get to Ireland. Just in case we couldn't get the thing in the air and had to row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks briskly down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuel was going to be so close, every single mile counted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns a corner.      Approaches the dining room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George told me to keep to my room, just in case there was a reporter or two somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters the hotel dining room. Stops cold. Across the room a disgruntled Bill and a sheepish Slim stare at her their breakfast, surrounded by 15 REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS. Holy shit. Half a dozen CAMERAS RISE as on It is a defining moment. And Amelia... Cocks her head.      Throws an effortless golden smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there, boys. How are the ham and eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FLASHES EXPLODE as one.   They keep POPPING as Amelia makes her way to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't blame us, lady. I think somebody's starting to sell books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reporters are handing her their morning editions. The New York Times front page headline: BOSTON GIRL STARTS FO ATLANTIC HOP. There beneath the headline, the glamorous PHOTO we watche being taken on the Copley Hotel roof, Lady Lindy. Next to it, an earlier photo of her as a demure social worker.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: melia is sifting through the other papers, grinning and shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Amelia. What have you got for Mabel Boll to chew on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why would a famous gal like Mabel give a thought to someone like me? I don't have a single sweater made out of gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys ROAR, Slim louder than anyone. Even Bill cracks smile. They're shouting, teasing, YOU CAN'T KID US!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, not even silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys make room.   Bill rises to hold Amelia's chair. friendly murmur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ham's a little tough, Commander. But the bacon's swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVIETONE NEWSREEL footage, accompanied by their signatur fanfare theme. Once more, the hotel conference room jamme with press. Today Mabel wears a luxurious silver fox coat shimmies up to a bank of microphones at the podium. Flash start POPPING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen of Diamonds Mabel Boll, upstaged by upstart social worker, seems madder than a rich wet hen. Hey Mabel, tell us about your rival!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound switches to Mabel leaning her sultry voice to t mikes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how would any woman feel about some tart who steals her man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reporters furiously writing, more flashes EXPLODE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Stultz and I were going to make history together, until this poor little social worker and her sugar daddy, oh excuse me, `publisher,' started throwing money and I don't know what else at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel, are you implying Miss Earhart used her feminine charms on your pilot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Charlie, I never seen her. Has she got any?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUGHTER, they're all calling out.   She shows them a smo smile, but stays on message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she had to use something on somebody to get from nowhere to here. You figure it out, or wait til George Putnam feeds it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dozen questions at once.   She's not even listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Canada, waiting for some good weather on the Atlantic, and then we'll kick Little Miss Whoozis in the keester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so cocky that she won't leave first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty, we can carry enough fuel to go to China. That thing they're flying can't load enough gas to make Yonkers. Tell that to Putnam's girlie. And while you're at it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snuggles the gleaming fox fur around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her I do wear silver.   So I'm two up on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 MOVIETONE NEWSREEL CONTINUES. We are looking at foggy, bl Trepassey Harbor as the Friendship makes an unsuccessful attempt to take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven days of failure for plucky Amelia Earhart and her crew. If it isn't storms over the Atlantic, it's the inability of the seaplane's pontoons to lift from the sea.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: ERIES OF ANGLES.    One failed take-off after another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it's for the best. Remember, no woman has beat the jinx of the Atlantic and three have died trying. Including a princess and the niece of former President Woodrow Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane's engine SPUTTERS and STALLS.     It floats on sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this one's not to be. Hey, Mabel! How's your weather report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Amelia coming down the hotel corridor. She passes a room, and hearing DRUNKEN LAUGHTER from a group of MEN within t room... She stops.    Stares at the door with more concern than a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, Slim and three of the REPORTERS are drinking up a storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXPLORER, MY ASS. BYRD COULDN'T FIND A PUBIC HAIR IN A WHOREHOUSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 Amelia curled up on her bed with CHARTS of the Atlantic spread everywhere. From next door, the sound of drunken m CONTINUE. Amelia looks down from her charts.       Her mind going t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 Seven-year-old KIDS dressed as cowboys and Indians are gathered on the front lawn of a white clapboard home. We CLOSE on a clear-eyed tomboy with war paint and tousled h AMELIA at seven, looking up excitedly as a car pulls to t curb.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: er FATHER climbs slowly from the car, WOBBLES his way acr the lawn. The kids part to let him through, the confusion and disappointment on every face. He ignores them all, ev Amelia. The front door opens... ...Amelia's MOTHER gazes at him with shame and disdain. she helps him stagger inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 Amelia in her flight gear, sitting on the edge of her bed open TELEGRAM lies beside her. Her elbows rest on her kne Her hands are locked together. Her profile is stony, determined. TILT DOWN to the telegram... It reads:    WEATHER PERMITTING, MABEL FLIES THIS AFTERNO She grabs her flight bag, leaves the room. She only has t travel as far as the next door. POUNDS on it. Waits. Pounds LOUDER with both fists. Slim opens the door.      Looking bad.   Bill sits up in groggy, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, what time is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to fly. Get up, get dressed, we're going now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is calm and angry at once.    A powerful combination. pulls his pants off a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the weather report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to his bed. Hands him a slip of paper.     He bl still waking up. Reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Maybe Mabel will think so, too. Because if she doesn't, she's going to Paris and you're going home. Today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine, there's a tail wind all the way, we'll off-load to 700 gallons, which gets us off the water and the wind gets us to Ireland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had better than this and we haven't gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this   is the day Mabel's ready, so we're   going now. The weather is going   to get better and we'll be there   to enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as serious as you're hung over. (to Slim) You go now, get the late weather, we'll meet you at the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Now! Slim pulls on his shoes, grabs his jacket, his bag. Looks to Bill, but the pilot is glaring at his commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim, get out. I've got this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Slim goes, the door shuts quietly.     Amelia sit the edge of Bill's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've loved one person unconditionally, Bill. He is the most caring and generous and charming and flat-out funny guy I'll ever know. He's my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are burning with this.    And Bill keeps quiet. Anyone would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a drunk. And he's let me down all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you get out of that bed. And you fly that god-damned thing to Ireland. Or I swear to you, Bill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just above a whisper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you I will. Or die trying.

dialogues.speaker: Y
dialogues.text: ou got that?   Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And either way. You're going to be living with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark and cold. Bill and Amelia stand at the dock bes their plane. He's drinking coffee as they watch Slim come down the quay with a slip of paper in his hand. Amelia st forward to take it. Reads with neutral eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.     Slim, start the engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still hasn't given the paper to Bill. Slim steps onto pontoon. Starts CRANKING up the propellers. As the engine KICKS to life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the weather report to Bill.    He reads.   Look her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You signed a contract. You've got a direct instruction from me to go. That report indicates some degree of risk and it's a risk I'm taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She motions to Slim, get on board. The navigator grins, starts to climb up, looking back at Bill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm scared shitless of this dame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs up after him.   One look back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read tomorrow's papers, Bill. We'll both be in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And disappears. Alone on the dock, Bill hears the engines REV. Jesus, God, she's going to do it. He takes a step toward the plane, but her head appears in the hatch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, to take off, you pull back on the thing, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her perfectly straight, innocent face.    He BUSTS out laughing. This fucking girl.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: osses his coffee.   Climbs aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 WITH Amelia as she locks the hatch. For the first time, w can see the inside of the plane. The cabin is too small f anyone to stand. The plane has been emptied of everything but two huge elliptical FUEL TANKS. he wedges herself between the gigantic tanks. Bill pulls the throttle and the Fokker Tri-motor LURCHES forward, STRAINING against the surface of the sea in a rattling, throbbing desperately VIBRATING all-out attempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia crawls to the tiny window, her face to the glass a chop and spray FLY PAST like shrapnel, and the engines WH and PULSE louder... ...twenty seconds, thirty. Still on the surface. Forty seconds, fifty, her eyes shut, her forehead bangs against glass, come on, sixty seconds, and at 67...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the seaplane LIFTS, struggles, then SOARS FREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Amelia kneels at the tiny window. A kid on a rainy day. Only outside this window is impenetrable FOG and a STORM ROCKS the plane like the shock waves of endless explosion As she braces herself against the hull... ...water DRIPS onto her from a loose seam. Could this be dangerous? She looks around. Through the opening between the elliptical fuel tanks... ...Bill and Slim at the controls. Bill is banging on something beside the instrument panel. Beneath his seat, sees the TOOLBOX. The water drips on her faster. She craw forward toward the boys, arriving to see... ...Bill POUNDING what we can now see is his RADIO.   His is red, angry. She watches for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU OKAY?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BE BETTER IF OUR DAMN RADIO WOULD JOIN THE PARTY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never turns to her, but she studies him. Is he impaire or simply frustrated? She slips the toolbox from beneath seat and crawls back to the leak. But as she opens the box... ...there, among the wrench and pliers, a BOTTLE of whiske She stares at it as we SNAP TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAPID SERIES OF ANGLES. War-painted Amelia looking up fro the cowboy she's tied to a tree. The car pulling to the curb. Out climbs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...her FATHER glassy-eyed.   Stumbling through the childr Her MOTHER at the door. ANGLE. Amelia still in war paint enters her parents' room She knows just where to go. Opens a drawer, digs beneath crisply starched shirts. Finds the BOTTLE. ANGLE. Amelia in the bathroom, POURING the bottle out int the sink. She looks up in the mirror to see... ...her father in the doorway. She turns straight to him. MEETS his eyes, direct and unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK to Amelia with Bill's bottle, as the battered plane lurches every which way in the storm. She lifts it from t toolbox. Hides it in the camera bag, as suddenly the plan DROPS fifty feet, and Amelia is SLAMMED against the ceili then crashes back to the floor. Dazed, she sees Bill turn around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ONTO SOMETHING FOR CHRISSAKE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She GRABS the leg of the navigation table which has been bolted down. Stares out the window, wondering if she'll m it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Dad. Hooray for the last grand adventure. I wish I had won, but it was worthwhile anyway. You know that.     I have no faith we'll meet anywhere again, but I wish we might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on the gray eyes.   DISSOLVE TO... LATER. Amelia at the window, still opaque with fog. Suddenly, the plane SWOOPS down toward a clearing in the clouds. There to the south, a FREIGHTER running across ou path. No land in sight.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: melia SCRAWLS a note, ties it to an ORANGE from her fligh bag, and crawls back to the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOW FAR TO LAND?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are studying the freighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RADIO'S   STILL OUT. NO WAY TO COMPUTE   WINDSPEED AND DRIFT IN THE FOG, SO   GOD ONLY KNOWS WHERE IRELAND   IS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NINETEEN HOURS PLUS. WE'VE GOT MAYBE AN HOUR OF PETROL LEFT. PROBABLY LESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shows him the note and the orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WESTERN UNION, SPECIAL DELIVERY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill has to smile. Are you serious? As a heart attack. Okay, he tries to get closer to the ship, but we're jerke and buffeted as we swing past and Amelia... ...DROPS the orange toward the freighter, watching the he winds CARRY it two hundred yards WIDE of the mark. Our th stare grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IF WE LAND NEAR THEM, WE'VE GOT A RESCUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes are locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THINK THOSE RIDICULOUS SKIS COULD HOLD US UP IN THIS KIND OF SEA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been wondering the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU SAID WE WERE GOING TO MAKE IT. ARE YOU A LIAR?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOT ON THIS OCCASION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rare smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WELL, THEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And SWOOPS back on course.   Amelia's hand squeezes his shoulder. DISSOLVE TO... LATER. Amelia crouched behind Bill's seat.       Fog star break up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face drawn, she almost seems to be holding her breath Something down below. As we drop, we hear the engines

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHEN'S THAT HOUR OF FUEL RUN OUT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EIGHTEEN MINUTES AGO.   WHY?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances over to Slim, who is busy unwrapping a sandwi She can't believe this. He takes a healthy bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE LONGER I OBSERVE MEN THE MORE I AM AWESTRUCK. BY THEIR CAPACITY FOR DENIAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crawls back to the navigation table. As she looks out her window, a SANDWICH SAILS past! She WHIPS around...Sli arms raised in jubilation. Down below... Land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 The little plane sputtering, shuddering, as Bill drops in a splashdown. We PAN to the shore... ...a rural railroad dock. Deserted except for THREE WORKE who glance up as the Friendship taxis to a buoy a few hun yards offshore. Amelia at the hatch, tiny in distance, WA a towel... ...one friendly worker takes off his coat and WAVES back. Then all three guys go back to work. SNAP TO... REVERSE ANGLE. From the Friendship, we watch the workers ignoring us. Bill and Slim HOLLER and jump up and down on the pontoons. Nobody cares. Amelia sits in the doorway, h legs swinging free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of gas. May have to swim for I t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Amelia alone. Six pages written by her side. Still working, as a rowboat pulls up. Bill stands in the bow. Calls to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Putnam phoned. He says there's fella coming from London. Hilton Railey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeh. Very important man.   More important than any of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?    Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says ya mustn't come ashore til he gets here. No matter what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.    She doesn't like it, but there it is.   She wav long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kind of royalty, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public relations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goes back to work.    DISSOLVE TO... LATER. Amelia sits with her papers in her lap, dangling h feet from the hatch. Alone. Hear the BUZZ of... ...a PLANE dropping slowly from the sky, gliding onto the water on its pontoons. She stares at it. Gathers up her things. LATER. Amelia sitting in a tiny dinghy, behind her the Friendship in distance. She is being rowed to shore. Our VIEW is over the back of the man rowing. Amelia is starin past him, vaguely apprehensive. REVERSE ANGLE. She's looking at TWO THOUSAND WELSHMEN swarming the docks. You can't even see the sand. The crowd is silent and staring. No cheers. As if they we staring at an alien or an animal in the zoo. Bill and Sli help pull the dinghy to the rocky shore. But when Amelia jumps out, the crowd... . ..begins to soberly APPLAUD, and slowly CLOSES IN around her. At first she seems pleased, trying to shake every ha thrust toward her. She doesn't see that Bill and Slim hav been shunted to the back. Suddenly... ...people get BOLDER. CLAPPING her on the back, reaching TOUCH her, someone SNATCHES her scarf, she looks around frantically for Bill and Slim as... ...a SHERIFF and three DEPUTIES muscle their way to her u billy clubs to push people back. They surround Amelia, be to escort her to the station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Ma'am. Shoulda brought more men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, this is very sweet, it's an honor. I'm actually enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him as they are jostled along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're stuck with it. From here on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is brought to a smiling avuncular HILTON RAILEY, stan beside the closest thing Burry Port has to a limo. She throws an affectionate arm around him, kisses his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hullo, Hilton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Railey stands back as FLASHBULBS catch the moment.   He's brought photographers with him. And more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia, say hullo to Allen Raymond of the New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hearty handshake.   She holds out her sheets of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you've come for these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men regard the pages as if they were gold bullion. for these indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 MOVIETONE FOOTAGE of Amelia being welcomed by a SEA OF PE on the dock at Southampton. A mob . Folks spilling into t water. Ships circling, fireboats spray, every craft BLARE its horn. Police hold back the screaming throng as FLASHE EXPLODE and NEWSREEL CAMERAS CHURN. Amelia at the center the storm. Welcomed by AMY GUEST and the lady LORD MAYOR Southampton. Throughout, we see SUPERIMPOSED IMAGES of the article she gave Railey, displaying her byline, on the front pages of London Times, New York Times, the Times of India, Sydney Morning Herald, the Toronto Star, Le Monde, as her story echoes around the world. These IMAGES CONTINUE OVER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK SERIES OF ANGLES. Amelia cheering animatedly at the races...watching tennis at Wimbledon...front row gallery the House of Commons, as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whirlwind week for Boston's Amelia Earhart, our own Lady Lindy. Races at Ascot on Gold Cup day...watching Helen Wills Moody play at Wimbledon...Lady Astor's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3              guest at the House of Commons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 MOVIETONE NEWSREEL CONTINUES. The British press are gathe in a huge Victorian parlor. Dark woods, rich leather, a b of microphones, an electric expectancy... Bill and Slim stand next to a seated Amy.    Amelia steps the microphones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a passenger on this journey. Just a passenger. Everything that was done to bring us across was done by Wilmer Stultz and Slim Gordon. All the praise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) But you can fly, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia stares at the man.    Conflicting agendas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This flight was solely to the credit of Bill and Slim. Women should know, however, that I have had 500 hours solo flying and once held the women's altitude record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you could have done it yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This particular flight, under these conditions, I wonder if anyone but Bill Stultz could have pulled it off. But certainly, one day a woman will do this. As easily, as skillfully, as professionally as any man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such calm self-possession.    Such confidence in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aviation is clear today for the pioneer. And if the pioneer has good ideas nobody will ask whether

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P            the pioneer is a man or woman. olite applause.       Mostly from women.   She looks arou room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear your doubt. That doubt is our challenge. This is where our Atlantic flight, or any other good flight by a woman can help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.    To them, to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It starts women thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 Ticker tape PARADE down Broadway, crowds lining the stree leaning from windows to welcome Amelia home.

dialogues.speaker: UPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Amelia sits in an open car between Bill and Slim, WAVING everyone. In the front seat, George and Dorothy share the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 Amelia flanked by George and Dorothy, coming out of a reception hall. Amelia glances to George...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you can burn those letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy wonders.       Letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saved them for your book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One simple shake of Amelia's head.       A soft...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book's yours.     The letters are mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.       Bows in submission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou're the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's my job. (to Amelia) Do you think there's enough of him to boss for the two of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia still looking at George.    Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely enough for one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battery of reporters and flashbulbs wait by our motorca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Earhart, can you tell us some- thing about your future plans?

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: he likes this question.    Fixes the man with that clear, honest gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, being a social worker by trade and passion, I'll be going back to work at Denison House when all this fun is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sends the guy a smile, and a dozen FLASHES catch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if I haven't been fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George holds the door of their limo. She looks up to him with a mischievous smile. And with no warning... ...Amelia bypasses the limo, climbs into the SIDECAR of a cop's motorcycle, and SMACKS its side. The cop looks up t George, who... ...nods, go for it. And the cop DOES, wheeling out into traffic, opening up the SIREN, as everyone laughs or chee or darts into the street desperate for a fleeting photo. George watching her go.    Dorothy watching George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Putnam, sir. How did a social worker like Miss Earhart become comfortable as a celebrity so quickly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George smiles.   His eyes still following Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, she was a celebrity on smaller stages all her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE(cont'd) This is just when the rest of us discovered her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Dorothy.   Watches this, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia in a sunlit garden ringed by trees. She sits at a folding table, writing longhand. A large dog lies at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they took me home with them to Rye. And I lived there, while I wrote my book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to see our view has been George's. He sits at a antique writing desk, watching her through a picture wind He rises slowly. We see that he has been reviewing a CONTRACT, which he takes with him.

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: NGLE. Amelia writing, looking up to see George coming dow the back porch steps to the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he'd be a tyrant and that I would have to manage him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles as he approaches.   She goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead he was kind and generous. And only picked the fights he needed to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the contract on her table.     She looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky Strike endorsement.      I wrote the copy myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it say?   `I don't smoke but you should?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says Lucky Strikes were the only cigarettes aboard the Friendship. That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True and misleading.      Why would I sign that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Bill and Slim get paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   His smile simple, comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're too proud to take tobacco money, donate it to Byrd's expedition, and we get great publicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him with hard eyes. His smile just becomes more relaxed. An easy win, no big deal. She begins to sig the contract. He places a stack of letters in front of he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This week's marriage proposals. The top one's the most creative. It's from Sing Sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to read.    Her eyes widen.   Goodness. AMELIA (reads) `...in the prison yard, so everyone can watch and share in our...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looks up) Did you write the copy on this one, too? DOROTHY (O.S., approaching) Have you no shame, George? No sense of the scandal you create?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up.   She has a tray of lemonade and cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make her work for nothing. At least you can feed her. (to Amelia) Are you done yet? If not, make him write the rest, he will anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 A women's college.    The hall is packed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lecture and publicity schedule was fierce. I was with her pretty much all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia and George alone in the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the moment of opportunity. Could we launch her into Lindbergh status as a permanent icon, before her name fell out of the news- papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He re-ties her scarf.   Checking out the effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had separate agendas. For her, it was the advancement of aviation and of women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He very slightly rearranges her hair, as if every lock matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for me, I liked to tell myself it was about the money. Though there was never much of that left over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands for inspection, with her trace of a teasing sm He holds out his hand and she gives him her note cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, it was about the chance to be around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips through the A cards, frowning as he goes. MELIA (George imitation) This will never do, A.E., simply unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up.   She starts pacing around, gesturing as he would... AMELIA (George imitation) You need more ammunition in these cards, and where's the goddamned humor, for Chrissake? By which I mean something actually funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to look annoyed.   It isn't easy. AMELIA (George imitation) And please remember not to turn your pretty little backside to the crowd when you use your pointer, it's your face they're paying to see. Well, most of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She WHIPS around.   He's deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA (George imitation) And another thing. Your hats. Are a menace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at each other. GEORGE (softly) Everything about you. Is a menace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stare holds.   Because this is the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the first kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only one step.     Her hand goes to his chest.    H close, as... She brings her mouth to his.     Tender and strong.    An It is an act of decision. A held look. No one smiles. We hear her name ANNOUNCED fr the podium. But she keeps looking at him. And as the APPLAUSE CONTINUES, she finally... ...turns. STRIDES onto the stage, with one graceful wave, she brings the applause to a crescendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I knew all the stories T hat Dorothy had been having a torrid affair with Fred Upton. Everyone did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps to the microphone.     The crowd quiets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't kiss him because I felt sorry for him. Or because it would mean the world to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT.   George in the wings.    His heart in his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it.    Because I wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down.   He's still holding her cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Hotel corridor. An elevator OPENS and ELINOR SMITH a striking young woman emerges. Looks at a slip of paper. Nervous. Heads down the hallway to a door. As she gathers herself to knock, she looks scared enough to pass out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George answers the door, looking gracious and suave. They shake hands. Then, Amelia appears, warmly clasping the girl's hand, and Elinor looks as starstruck as a teenager the Oscars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so good to meet you. I've been following your career with a great deal of admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um.   Thanks, and.   You, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia!   What would her mother say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, George. I meant a Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leads Elinor into the sitting room of their suite, girl's eye falls on the door to the bedroom. It is slight ajar, revealing an unmade double bed. Unseen by the other the kid reacts. Oh, my.

dialogues.speaker: L
dialogues.text: ATER. Tea in the sitting room.    Elinor leaning forward, guileless, eager...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're saying you get $500 a week on the lecture circuit. GEORGE                          AMELIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a bad week.                  On a good week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All depends. On whether you want the sell or the real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't underestimate the value of selling. It's why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 16-year-old girl sets an altitude record, then makes headlines illegally flying under the four bridges of the East River. You don't seem to need much help selling yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually Mr. Putnam, I was hoping you could do to me what you've done to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inadvertently, her eyes flick to the bedroom door. Catchi this, our couple shares a dry smile. The kid sees that. U oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is. It's a good thing. That's why I want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now our couple is trying not to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so we're clear, young lady. What is your primary ambition? ELINOR (straight back) To take Amelia's place as the number one female pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honesty, the suddenness, leave George atypically dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good for you! I would have expected nothing less. You want a tip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep doing what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl nods, seriously.    Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't let anyone turn you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Holiday party in progress. Christmas decorations everywhe A small crowd around the living room bar where George is telling a story. Now we see Dorothy standing, drinking, watching George wi hard eyes. She turns on her heels and walks OUT into the garden. George sees this, excuses himself, follows her, a we PAN to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Amelia standing with a group of guests.    She's seen all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she comes along the roses, still drinking, still fum A figure comes up behind her. Falls in step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely party, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on your point of view. I've been listening to some idiot brag about his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still walking.   She never looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in that case, for your information, it is a lovely party indeed. Anything on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so much that my husband is having an affair with his meal ticket. It's just a pity we can't have one honest conversation about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with this one? A promising start, I'd say, in the honesty department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes her drink. Throws the glass away. From our ANGLE we can now see D Amelia in the window, watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is what you call an honest talk, I'd say you need some practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Let's try one about you and Fred Upton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops walking.   Turns in shock, to see his easy smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm waiting for our practice conversation. Hoping I'll learn something. About honesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She GLARES at him, and storms off. He lets her go. Hear a car engine TURN OVER. Dorothy PEELING OUT. George reflect As he walks back toward the party, he now sees Amelia in window. He stops. Their look holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 George at the kitchen table in dim light. It's very late. HAND places a steaming mug of coffee before him. Followed a slice of pie. A fork. He smiles. And softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy and I are through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits beside him.     Very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's different now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.   Squints.    How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   A breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you give it a chance, you'll learn to love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems so sunny and strong.     What can he be feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already love you.    That's why I can't marry you. GEORGE (a murmur) Well, that explains it. For a minute there, I thought you were stuck for an excuse.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: he comes close enough to kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know me.     And you don't.   Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I promise not to learn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day will come. When I will run away. And when it does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops her with a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you love me. I'll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares in her troubled eyes.   There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race you to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Amelia and nearly 20 WOMEN lined up in front of planes. Waving, smiling, talking to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia Earhart and a bevy of lovely competitors say hello to the press announcing the First Women's Air Derby, racing from Santa Monica to Cleveland. Dubbed by Will Rogers `the Powder Puff Derby,' these gals certainly know how to capture our attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next ANGLE shows Amelia watching some of her colleagu bouncing playfully on a see-saw. She smiles tolerantly, b maybe there's a little too much cheesecake for her taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 The crowded waiting room. We CLOSE on a young woman we scarcely recognize. It is Elinor. Though less than a year has passed, she seems much older. Sophisticated, poised. ANGLE. A secretary leads Elinor down the corridor to George's office. As they enter, George is pacing on the phone.              G EORGE (into phone) Because Amelia invented the Powder Puff Derby for female pilots. Then the men running the damn race suddenly decide every woman has to carry a male navigator, and start from east of the Rockies so they won't crash into the mountains!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listens, impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE (into phone) I'll tell you why it's a front page story. Because Amelia pulled every woman out of the race. So the organizers had to roll over and give in, or they'd have lost their shirts. You want me to write your headline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances over.   Elinor in the doorway. GEORGE (into phone) Call you back. I've got a very important guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, gesturing graciously for her to sit.   As sh does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I was important enough for you to manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've just got one client. And most days she's more than I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Elinor's smile seems older, more capable of subtlety

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in line behind the boys she smacked around on the Derby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins back.   You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the gal flyers had their doubts about her...well, her skill level. But she's everyone's champion now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And both of those things.      Are the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S         reasons I called you. trange words.   He has her attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it would be huge for women flyers if Amelia won the Derby. The publicity would put the race, and all of you, up there with the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure she has much of a chance, Mr. Putnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the one shot would be putting her in a far more powerful plane than anything she's flown. We're thinking the Lockheed Vega.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl's shock.    He really means this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I've test piloted the Vega. It's way more than she could ever handle. It wouldn't be safe, let alone successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I'm thinking of you flying with her. You could handle the cross-country flying, the more difficult bits, and I'd pay you $75 a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elinor WHISTLES low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think that's the most generous opportunity I've ever been offered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just one thing. Obviously, it has to appear that Amelia did all the flying. So when pictures are taken, you'll stand off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes narrow.    He's completely serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, I'll get my own plane and win the race myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't changed.

dialogues.speaker: N
dialogues.text: o smile at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately for you, neither have I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look in his eye is not to be ignored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't win if you can't get a plane to enter. Let me predict that you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice calm and low and riveting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact. If you reject my generosity, you may come to regret it. For a long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an intensely loyal person, Elinor. And this is what my loyalty requires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's glaring.   Reeling.   Trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the one who said I shouldn't let anybody turn me around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She probably meant me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So honest, the words confuse her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously, she doesn't see me as a threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure she does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A straight smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just doesn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
