dialogues.text: ...which silently fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job.     Is to care for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG ANGLE. Sophisticated watering hole. Crowded tonight. PAN to find George alone, waiting. A waiter leads Amelia the table. George stands, smiling. But the smile is not returned. We CLOSE as they sit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hat's wrong? MELIA (clearly furious) What could be wrong? I had such a lovely afternoon with Elinor Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he told you that I shut her out of the Derby. And that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when were you going to tell me? GEORGE (calm, straight) Never. I knew you'd go crazy. And I felt it needed to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can scarcely believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You think I wanted it done, but just let you do the dirty work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm no angel. Business is competition and competition is rough, and I thank my stars that you're there making this life happen for me, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou're making your life hap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If women are going to stab women in the back, then women are going nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rom here on, I'll just stab men in he back. A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't do this for business, anyway.   G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it for fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it because you love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when we're married, you mustn't ever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she stops.      Because his eyes are wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the big shock? I thought you wanted to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: did.   I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes moving over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about what you said? The day

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S            will come when you run away. he nods.    It will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be destroyed. And part of me will, too. And I think we both know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes things happen that way. You're not better safe than sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears stand in his eyes.       He is so happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA (a whisper) (CONT'D) Yes? GEORGE (a whisper) Hell yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a window, a dry, wintered garden. Snow falling, a once soft and heavy. Beyond, Morgan Point Lighthouse, Fisher's Island Sound, Long Island Sound. One lonely fish boat braves the cold water. PULL BACK to see... ...Amelia at the breakfast table in a windowed room. writing, and as she does...

dialogues.speaker: UPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: ...her eyes are swimming with tears.     She brushes at t Stares down at her work. Continues. ANGLE. The parlor. George, his MOTHER, the MINISTER, a small number of close FRIENDS. From the doorway, Amelia beckons George. The letter is in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 Amelia holds tight to George's hand, leading him out into falling snow. She turns, fixes him with a look. Hands him the letter. And steps back. As if giving him space. At first, he smiles. What is this? She gestures for him t read. As he begins, there is nothing for a few seconds. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I want you to understand I shall not hold you to any medieval code of faithfulness to me. Nor shall I consider myself bound to you similarly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falling.    Absolute silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can be honest I think the difficulties which may arise may best be avoided should you or I become interested deeply, or in passing, with anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gazes intently, her heart in her eyes.     He never l up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let us not interfere with the other's work or play, nor let the world see our private joys or disagreements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must exact a cruel promise. And that is you will let me go in a year if we find no happiness together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops on this.    His thoughts unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will try to do my best in every way. And give you that part of me you know and seem to want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds the letter carefully.    Places it in his pocket smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y Amelia. Brutal in her frank- ness. Beautiful in her honesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps to her.    Looks in her eyes.   They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG ANGLE. The minister reading the vows. The witnesses standing silent. Two black cats rubbing against George's ankles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 George at the breakfast table. His eggs and toast ignored for the moment, he's reading a magazine article. PAN to Amelia, sipping her coffee. Watching him. GEORGE (reads aloud) `Why I Believe Women Pilots Can't Fly The Atlantic. An outspoken warning by Lady Heath.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `...pure suicide for any woman today...it is madness for them to attempt it and...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `...at least the first dozen will be drowned.' And we're reading

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: this, because...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might fly to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is actually across the Atlantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hence, the article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.   He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of doing it solo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He butters his toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. When would you like to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 CLOSE on Amelia as she kneels, carefully putting new plan into the ground. We see patience, concentration. Contentment. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised you're all right with this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN ANGLE.     George kneeling beside her.   Happily pl his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmmn. I was braced for the lecture. Five years since Lindbergh, no one's made it solo, so many of them died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her work. Reaches over. Starts packing the earth HARDER around her plant. She just watches, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ell, they were only men.   This is different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches to his plant and starts LOOSENING the soil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was waiting to hear that I'm only doing this because I was just a passenger last time, and I'd rather die than go on living as a fraud..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one cracks a smile. It's like Laurel and Hardy in a fo fight where each lets the other take his best shot. Georg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reaches now, starts REPACKING her soil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't think that, do you, ear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. But if I did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She SMACKS his hand. He just keeps working. She finally grins, smacks him HARDER. He doesn't seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...all the more reason to say yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 AERIAL ANGLE. In the sun's last light, two figures walk slowly, far below us. The Vega waits. CLOSE ANGLE. They stand beneath the wing. Her ground crew in far distance, giving them their moment. Her look is no breezy and cavalier this time, but tender and intimate. S knows the fear beneath his easy smile. He produces a RING, a band of black fibers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elephant hair, I think you wear it on your toe. It's good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts it in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. That's what the elephant told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia looks at the ring.   Turns it in her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think luck has rules. And I try to respect them. My favorite is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We make our own luck, you and I. Remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will remember that.    And more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out a twenty dollar bill.      Hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this? G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank god, I thought you were going to tear it in half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent our money on ocean liner passage to go bring you back. It's non-refundable. So try to do your part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.   She'll try.   He doesn't want to leave her ye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the Simpkin thing. What was all that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put it in a letter. Which you'll get if I don't make it. So...mixed emotions, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head. GEORGE (very soft) Either way, something to look forward to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hands on his face.    She doesn't want to le him either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA (murmurs) Stake up the peonies, huh? They're messy when they bloom on the ground, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And. AMELIA (a whisper) I want to see their heads high. When I come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans up to kiss him. And again.    Feeling in her ey that he will never forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 Amelia alone. Starry night.   12,000 feet below are ICEBE A single fishing boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weather report wasn't perfect. But we knew our real chance was to take weather that others wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, towering CLOUDS in moonlight.   Too high to fly ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I closed the deal by choosing May 20, five years to the day from Lindbergh's flight. It was too good a sell for George to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5              What we didn't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 A terrifying STORM BATTERS the plane, which bobs and dart and dips like a leaf in a gale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...was that my altimeter would conk out. Never to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 Amelia fights for control as the plane is TOSSED and SHAK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way to have any sense of altitude, was to keep dropping toward the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA(cont'd) When the engines sputtered, that was my low-level limit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden JOLT knocks her OUT of her seat. She scrambles back, as we see WHITECAPS A FEW FEET BELOW. She JERKS the nose UP, the engine COUGHS... ...and CLIMBS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was too busy to grasp how impossible the situation had become. The joke was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER.   Flying in and out of cloud cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those months flying only with instruments, I should have been practicing without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN to the windshield. A small GLOW at the surface of a vibrating engine. Amelia hasn't noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started to wonder if luck was paying me back. For thinking I knew the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small BLUE FLAME LICKS out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I smelled burning oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees it now. The flame coming through a broken weld i the manifold ring.  A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bad weld, already a small flame. It would be hours back to Canada, trying to find an unlit field, landing with a heavy fuel load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at the little flame.   Is it growing bigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told myself, push on. After all, if it was a stupid choice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Flying in blackness.    Rising, as the engines see sluggish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no one would ever know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a FILM of SLUSH on the windscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With seemingly no warning, there was ice. The controls froze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Vega DIVES into a DIZZYING SPIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the spin I had one thought, it would be warmer lower, the ice would melt, I just had to regain control...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SPINNING plane PLUNGING...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...before I hit the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ARCING at last to SWOOP above the whitecaps.   Way cl for comfort. SMASH CUT TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 Amelia REELING in her seat, her fingers FUMBLING in her flight bag, for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or passed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...SMELLING SALTS, she inhales, again, blinks, starts to climb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ice happened twice more, and I began to lose heart. Then I remembered Lindbergh's book saying the same thing happened to him.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: he sea DISAPPEARS below.   Only cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I figured, if he's twice as good, I just have to be twice as lucky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOURS LATER. Amelia seriously fatigued. She breaks throug cloud into DAZZLING SUNLIGHT, and blinks, blinded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd read that part in George's reception room that first day. Bless him for keeping me waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FUEL GAUGE reads EMPTY. She switches on the RESERVE TANK. And as she DROPS back down into opaque clouds... ...she feels something. Her fingertips go to her left shoulder, and come away... Wet.   Slick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cockpit gauge was defective. There was a steady trickle of fuel down my neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around helplessly for a way to stem the drippin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toss-up whether the bigger danger was running out of gas or going up in a fireball. I had my answer in less than an hour, when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Amelia beyond exhaustion. Staring fixedly at some- thing we can't see. Until we PAN through the wind screen the leak in the manifold weld. The BLUE FLAME is startlin LARGER, now LICKING its way along the surface of the fuselage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manifold weld began to separate. I gauged the likelihood of explosion at somewhere between probable and inevitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Arms folded, George stares out his window. He hasn't slep or eaten. PAN to his desk. The phone is OFF the hook. The door opens softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Putnam? Line three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and looks at her. The girl's eyes go down and he BOLTS to the phone, SNATCHES the receiver, SLAMS the button... GEORGE (into phone) Putnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, this is Douglas McGuire of the Press Association. I'm sorry to tell you that Miss Earhart's plane has crashed in a field, short of Le Bourget airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 A plane swooping downward through cloud and fog.   The SO of George's call CONTINUES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the crash is as reported, sir, I'm afraid not. There were terrible flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOWER, it's dropping fast, maybe too fast, WOBBLES in a crosswind, here comes the GROUND, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they completely sure it's her plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Vega RIGHTS itself and GLIDES in for as fine a lan as a bumpy meadow could allow. COWS look up as she rolls past, toward... ...one lone astonished FARM WORKER.   She cuts her engine leans from the hatch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blink.   The truth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Gallagher's pasture.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: ne more beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are ya supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I left, I was aiming for Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. MAN (very sad) Ya missed, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over there.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEW YORK HARBOR- DAY
dialogues.text: 58 MOVIETONE NEWSREEL FOOTAGE of Amelia arriving at New York Harbor to an overwhelming reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia Earhart arrives to a tumul- tuous New York reception after her whirlwind tour of Europe, in which our Queen of the Skies danced with her royal counterpart the Prince of Wales, before meeting both Benito Mussolini and the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAYOR, the GOVERNOR, every dignitary that could get a invitation is there to greet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second human to fly the Atlantic solo, she is the only one ever to fly it twice. And she set the record, man or woman, for the fastest crossing. Fourteen hours 54 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she waves to the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's America's turn to show our girl what we think of her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 We are standing in the wings. Through the curtains, we GLIMPSE the eager, packed house in an auditorium. From th stage, a speaker DRONES, but backstage... ...George peeks out at the throng. When he looks back, we see Amelia, her troubled face. The folded newspaper in he hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA (reads) `Only an average flyer, she has pushed herself to the front by following the tactics of the feminists...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ell, I'm glad someone besides me finally noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His smile is light.    Her eyes watching him.   Then... AMELIA (reads) `Using a man-made perfect machine, tuned by men mechanics, trained by men flyers, on a course laid out by a man. By a lucky break she just managed to make the hop.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at the paper.    His voice comes gently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hy would you even read that garbage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it reminds me how much I owe to the men of this world. Keeps me humble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ood. And remembering how little you owe me keeps me humble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a crackpot. Let it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the packed hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up.     They're crazy about you. AMELIA (quiet) Well, they're crazy about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down.   Self-doubt flickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we really done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made them feel like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of them are women. And for them, it's very much enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The World Telegram said, `a magnificent display of useless courage.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is. Can any magnif- icent display of courage be use- less?     A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is. Men do it every day. And no one throws a parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.   Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day closer, then. To the day when they won't think to throw one for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't turn.   She doesn't smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reasoning with me. A magnificent display of useless courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And.   It's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the stage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADIES AND GENTLEMEN. THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIL TO THE CHIEF strikes up. We hear the deep applause. George begins to straighten Amelia's outfit, touching her hair, as he did long ago on the Copley Hotel roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GOLD MEDAL OF THE NATIONAL GEO- GRAPHIC SOCIETY WAS LAST AWARDED FIVE YEARS AGO TO COL. CHARLES LINDBERGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George murmurs close to her ear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a bomb goes off tonight, the whole government of the United States is out there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT HAS NEVER BEEN AWARDED TO A WOMAN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some dog catcher will have to become President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.    Just for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNTIL TONIGHT. GEORGE (a whisper) Boy. Imagine if you'd actually done something. AMELIA (a whisper) Imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT IS MY HONOR TO WELCOME TO CONSTI- TUTION HALL, A ROLE MODEL FOR LADIES EVERYWHERE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS AMELIA EARHART. M           GEORGE iss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's through the curtain, and the crowd CRACKLES with APPLAUSE as... ...George stands in the wings.   Proud.    And concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train rumbles through countryside.    A private compart finds Amelia staring out the window.    George studying h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The irony is, I'd finally put that wedding day letter out of my mind. Stopped watching every beautiful accomplished man who crossed her path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ANGLE. Through the glass of our compartment door, crowd stands jouncing against each other. Gazing at their Queen of the Skies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a call from the Byrds. They've asked us to dinner Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday, I'll be in Boston. Meeting Gene Vidal and Paul Collins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said lightly. Not even looking at him.     While through glass, it's become quite a tussle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me Gene wants to resurrect Transcontinental?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's starting a shuttle service. Washington, New York, Boston...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One woman goes flying from view, as a younger one gets he place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be a money maker for us.    Get me off the lecture grind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares in her eyes.   Almost as if looking for somethi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene's a dashing guy. He could talk anyone into anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their look holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S ounds like a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN the dark, elegant restaurant. In a corner by the fire place, Amelia and her dinner companions are being served lobsters. GENE VIDAL leans to Amelia as he speaks, and sh hangs on every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transcontinental was too ambitious. Too many hops, too tough on the ladies. But the shuttle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lean athlete's body, easy grace in every movement. Strikingly handsome features that convey not only intelle but kindness and decency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington, New York, Boston. I think it's the future. Will you go there with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's trying to crack her lobster, but can't take her eye off her host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth would you need me for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's making a real mess of the lobster.    Gene notices. COLLINS doesn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't George taught you anything? Lady Lindy, the queen of the air, the best known woman in the entire U.S. of A?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene reaches over, as if it were his own plate, and begin cracking her lobster for her. She looks in his eyes and tries to concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene on the poster with you. Legendary athlete at West Point, two events in the Olympics, a top pilot who should be running the skies for Roosevelt when he wins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene looks up at Paul, as if to say: Enough. Now he smile at Amelia. She blinks, what? Don't you want your lobster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. She starts eating... ENE (looking only at Amelia) Thanks, Paul. I think you've even talked me out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Paul has gone. Gene and Amelia are at the bar, huddled over his beer and her Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene had a terrible marriage and was separated from his alcoholic adulterous wife. But he was too kind to humiliate her with a divorce...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene drains the last of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a result, he was basically a single parent to their young son, Gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at his watch.      Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm rattling on here, and you've got a morning train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's just staring in his eyes.   This could be her l chance to ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Nina doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   He smiles, gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, she hasn't been feeling her best. She'll probably summer in Newport. So my kid's stuck with Dad again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you two get bored, I could tag along sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suggesting you're less boring than I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles first.    Hers is slower, but here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any given meal, I can eat a lobster and have you boys in stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full beat.    He's deciding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore would love that. He has a little crush, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then. He breaks the look.     Fishes out some cash the bar tab.        G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Paul and I would be thrilled to rope you into our shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, it's a godsend. No matter how hard George and I work, how many lectures we cram in, there's never enough money for the next adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. Lets the silence sit there.     His eyes to convey a depth of understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next adventure.    What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs.    No idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we're running out of oceans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish you'd do something about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious, Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her soft smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.   Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way you can stay where you are. And be who you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serious indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is to keep feeding the beast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't smile anymore.     Because this is the very fea lives with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the beast always needs something larger, greater, more daring... AMELIA (quiet) He costs money, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The price of fame, literally. Do you and George talk about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all respect.    Yes, you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking together down the hallway of her hotel. No one speaks. Their thoughts are their own. She reaches her roo finds her key. Opens the door, and... ...turns to him. A brief, direct look.       She reaches gently behind his head. Leans up.

dialogues.speaker: K
dialogues.text: isses his mouth. AMELIA (a whisper) Thank you.

dialogues.text: His eyes question.

dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no smile. Without a word, she goes into her room CLOSES the door behind her. e stands alone. Do I knock on that door?     Then, smiles himself, and simply... Walks away.

dialogues.text: 63 Crowded hall, each table ringed by diners in formal dress At a table of honor, George sits next to Elinor Smith, chatting comfortably. PAN to the head table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Roosevelt won, his wife Eleanor brought the advancement of women to national attention with stunning success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, eating heartily, chatting, laughing with a companion we don't see until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gutsy gal who rode a bobsled in he Winter Olympics, spent hours each morning on horseback, and carried a pistol on car trips. She possessed boundless energy, a towering intellect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we reveal Amelia in a formal satin dress at her side, dishing with the First Lady like the closest of girlfrien

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and was Amelia's idol. As it happened, she was obsessed with flying, making Amelia her absolute heroine. A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he hasn't actually forbidden you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin doesn't forbid. He just feels it's a waste of my valuable ime to learn. Since I can't afford to buy a plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a look of such mutual understanding, neither h to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrong Roosevelt got elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it will take at least four years to correct the mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did ask about aviation, but he hasn't decided on the structure yet. It might be under the Bureau f Commerce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the structure may be less important than the man chosen to run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said casually, looking at her plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hearing is failing. I missed the words `or woman,' which you undoubtedly added after, or per- haps before, the word `man.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his could be one of those rare instances. When the most accomplished candidate. Turns out to be male.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glances up for the reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How exciting. I love finding the exception that proves the rule. Is t a name I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia's straight gaze.   Her small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel about flying at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor's eyes register the change of topic.     Rolling it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never done it.   Franklin finds t dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raucous party in the small cabin, hosted by George and fu . by champagne. PAN slowly to... ..the cockpit. Amelia at the controls in her evening dres and formal gloves. Eleanor in the co-pilot's seat, awestr by the brilliant starry night. Amelia glances over, moved her friend's almost childlike wonder. AMELIA (softly) Put your hands on the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor looks over.   Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dual controls.   No one will ever know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And slowly, Eleanor's fingers close on her wheel.     Ame hands come away from hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Condor purrs along through the night air. The moon bo slightly off to one side. Eleanor's eyes are swimming wit the thrill of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like a Coke.   Can I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stands up. Only the trace of her smile as the pilot's eyes WIDEN in absolute shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do try not to hit the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 A sea of press, quiet, poised, attentive.     REVERSE ANG to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...CLOSE on a seated Roosevelt before a bank of microphon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, we proudly announce an appointment critical to America's commerce, and to its role as technology's leader in the Twentieth Century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN to Gene at his side.   Sober.   Distinguished.   Prou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G ene Vidal is an obvious and perfect choice as our first Director of Commerce's Aeronautics Branch. His extraordinary credentials include...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 A taxi slowly pulls up to the home we know. Warmly lit, music playing from within. Gene climbs from the cab, as y lights go ON. As Gene starts up the path, the front door opens and Amel BURSTS into the night, RUNNING to Gene, JUMPING INTO his arms, HUGGING him in her delight. We PULL BACK to... George watching it all from the doorway.    His easy smil seems comfortably in place, as... ...Amelia walks Gene up the path, her arm around his wais talking excitedly, flushed as a schoolgirl. As they reach the door... George is the picture of calm and dignity. He beams and CLASPS Gene's hand. Throws an arm around his shoulder as Amelia leads them inside. The door closes.   We hear laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Amelia on her knees, tending to her garden. She seems hap and filled with energy. George comes and kneels beside he Starts weeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I told you what a perfect job ou did on the peonies? They're miraculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE (working) You have, actually. Twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. You've been distracted lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No spin on that.   If G anything, the tone is kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I've put together a month n Europe. Close some foreign licensing deals, open new markets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing is.     I'd like you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stiffens only slightly.     Can he sense it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really see how I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've talked to the promoters, they'll switch some lecture dates for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's looking at her profile.     Saddened, if not sur by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not just that. There's y work on the shuttle, we're at a critical stage, and...I've just started as Gene's consultant at the Aeronautics Branch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows he's watching.    Shakes her head.    Keeps on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normally, I'd be worried about leaving you here alone. But I suppose that won't be a problem, will it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops now. Looks up at him.      If he wants a direct conversation, he can have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've just said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long held look.       Neither backing away.   Sadness o sides. GEORGE (softly) Is there anything you want to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sighs.       Her fingers reach out, rub his hand with affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.   Well, then.      Rises slowly... Walks back toward the house, his garden tools forgotten. stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: e disappears into the house.       She's still staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 MOVIETONE NEWSREEL FOOTAGE introduced by its theme. A stadium in brilliant sunlight, filled with more than 100, people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los Angeles, California. The Tenth Olympics of the modern era kick off, as movie stars mingle with ordinary Joes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the track, WOMEN RUN the 100 meter high hurdles as eve throat CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the gold medal run of the world's best woman athlete, abe Didrickson. Cheered on by the most celebrated woman of today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT INSERT of Amelia with Gene and 8-year-old GORE, all applauding excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's right, Amelia Earhart. Hollywood glamor, American winners, and wait til our boys warm up for their action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera lingers as Amelia says something to Gore. look like a family.

dialogues.text: 69 CLOSE on George alone in his office.    He goes to the do LOCKS it. His face is drawn, grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time, I had a side job as chairman of the editorial board of Paramount Pictures. So Amelia and I bought a little place in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes slowly back to his desk.   On it, sits a large cardboard CARTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was out there, preparing for a flight, when our home in Rye burned to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE that the contents of the box, papers, small object have been SINGED or CHARRED. He stares into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both cried when I called to tell her. She asked to come be with me. But I insisted she stay there, to keep on schedule for her flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into the box...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many treasures lost. Letters and poems she'd written. I poured through the rubble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 Amelia curled up on the sofa of a cozy, pleasant little h The doors are open to the patio and yard. Winter is different here. Tropical flowers, fruit trees in bloom. T phone RINGS and she picks it up quickly, knowing it's Geo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA (softly) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. What's today been like?       You still okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT George at his office. He's standing at the windo phone in one hand, single sheet of paper in the other. Li the other objects in the box, it is partially singed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found something you'd written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draws a breath.     Reads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EORGE (reading) `To touch your hand or see your face today is joy. Your casual presence in a room recalls the stars that watched us as we lay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK to Amelia.     Tears fill her eyes. GEORGE (reading) I mark you in the moving crowd And see again those stars a warm night lent us long ago. We loved so then. We love so now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT George.     His eyes are dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for writing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.   His voice still softer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though I'd never seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on him.     The pain of what that must mean.    And.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO LOS ANGELES
dialogues.text: 71 Her lips are parted.       She's searching for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I thought.      It was too revealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN ANGLE. Gene enters the room with a drink in his han and sits down next to her, concerned by her obvious distr AMELIA (into the phone) I'm so glad you have it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA(cont'd) Of course. Me, too. I'll call you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up slowly. The tears begin to fall.    She look Gene helplessly. Then stands without a word. Walks out into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spectators at Newark Airport. A plane CIRCLES the field a FLOOD LIGHTS FLASH ON, and the crowd begins to CHEER. Arc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in now for a landing. Smooth trajectory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The odyssey began in Honolulu when he became the first person, man or woman, to fly solo over half the Pacific to California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touching down, the cheering CROWD held back by police. As Amelia taxies to a stop, the crowd BREAKS THROUGH police lines and SURGES toward the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the first human to solo from California to Mexico City. Followed by her daring solo across the Gulf. As she passed over Washington, D.C., she eclipsed the time of a certain previous flight, from 27 hours to 13 hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia hops down from the plane, grinning and waving.   S surrounded by adoring fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot of that previous flight? Some guy named Lindbergh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JOSTLING of the crowd gets out of control, the police can't protect her as she is SWEPT ALONG by the mob, beami laughing, enjoying it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Dark little piano bar. They sit in a quiet corner, com- fortable in silence. Gene with his martini, Amelia with h Coke. She's shelling peanuts from a bowl, popping some in her mouth, passing a few over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't drink, why do you come o bars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be the ambience.   And the nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What worries me is, in some of these bars the nuts are the ambience. Specially when they make a pass at you.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: he chews, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any guy would have to be nuts to do that. I'm considerable trouble, if you haven't noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep advertising that, but I'm still waiting to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at her fingers as they shell.    Barely audible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's your chance. I'm taking Gore to the conference in Bermuda. He wants you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   I'm completely indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would make life simpler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws a peanut which BOINKS off his face.    He smil suddenly goofy, very non-elegant smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'll be in Indiana. Edward Elliot of Purdue wants

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMELIA(cont'd) me to build a women's careers department there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   He likes that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back and forth. When I'm there, I've asked to stay in the dorm with the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a wonderful idea. Especially now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something in the way he said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's special about now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good time for some positive press about you as a role model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes harden.   Whatever do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't read the papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless someone makes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, someone should. Because they're all saying you took recklessly dangerous solo flights for no earthly purpose except publicity. Meaning, money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead.   Silence.     G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They also harp on a growing list of products that you commercially endorse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How thoughtless of me to be doing ll this in a society where no one else is interested in making money. Present company included.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not afraid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, George had you taking money rom the sugar cartel for the Hawaii flight, the Mexican Government for theirs, he's selling commemorative stamps which you carried on the flights...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is about George, just say o. Because we made those calls, nd we includes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I said it that way. This s actually about you, because I'm picking a fight, apparently a useless one, for the benefit of someone I care about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's your point? Women are eld to some higher standard? Bankers and industrialists are ad- mired for succeeding, but women are just considered selfish and grasping? ENE (quietly) Of course they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's change that, shall we? r would you just prefer to adopt t, since groveling would be easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to make money, my guess s that people viewing you as Lady Lindy, America's Sweetheart of the Skies, the wife/mother/daughter they all wished they had. Would be helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for not being defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm an open-minded girl. And o prove it, I'm hereby resigning as your consultant at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S            Aeronautics Branch. he throws some money on the table for the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public linking of our names does more harm to that image of mine than everything else put together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you read the papers.      Try reading between the lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walks out.       Gene makes no move to follow.   He's sai piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 MOVIETONE NEWSREEL FOOTAGE introduced by its theme. Again a backdrop of flowerbeds, Amelia is flanked by four WOMEN with conservative hats and middle-aged gravitas. The photographers edge closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to Washington today with the National Women's Party, to ask the President for his aid in passing the Lucretia Mott Amendment for equal rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for the press to quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's because I haven't needed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winsome smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the lucky one. Our Department of Commerce shows no prejudice in issuing licenses to fly. A pilot is a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about giving the rest of our women. The ones who can be productive for their families and for our nation an equal break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not defiant.      Gentle and strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are your sisters and your daughters. They are your wives. And fellas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smallest shake of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've no excuse. And you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o-Eds gathered in the common room in robes and nightgowns They fill the old couches, the mismatched easy chairs, cu up in blankets on the floor. PAN TO... ...Amelia in flannel pajamas, sitting on the grand piano, pointing to the next question among the many raised hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, it's all well and good to tell us to study whatever we want, and work at whatever we want, and not give a darn about what the world of men think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...including them wanting us to say darn instead of damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.   The girl flushes a little, her point is a cru one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about those of us who are getting married when we graduate? What advice do you have for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She meant that.      And no one is laughing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Build your career first. And, surprisingly, that's the best thing you can do for your eventual marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many eager faces, so many disturbed ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. It starts with a strong sexual attraction, that the oman assumes must be love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some heads are nodding.   Some eyes suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything works until the first financial crisis jars the man's confidence and threatens the oman's security. Why...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks from one to the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she can't help. All she can be is dependent. Because that I s what she's been trained to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone RINGS. One of the girls snatches it up to cut off the interruption. CO-ED #2 (hushed) Common room. Oh. Sure. (hand over phone, to AMELIA) He says he's the man in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia hops off the piano.   There are plenty of curious faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me. Only a husband talks like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In their laughter, she goes to the phone.      EVERYBODY every word of... AMELIA (into the phone) Yes?  Yes. Yes... (hand over phone, to the GIRLS) They love when we say `yes.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm flying in Tuesday. Yes, of course, I'll make time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too. Thanks for the roses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. Turns to her adoring pupils, and drops a curtsy. Ta-da! They APPLAUD. She stares at them. As if deciding whether to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you women keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can.   And boy, do they want to hear one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's no secret that I'm a bit driven, some might say obsessive, about my little flying adven- tures...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are nodding, wide-eyed, go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've decided to embark on easily the most exciting, possibly cra- ziest, ever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hold their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to fly. Around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frozen beat for them to even absorb this. They BURST in WILD APPLAUSE, Amelia beaming, as we DISSOLVE TO... 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Amelia and George, bundled against the cold, walking Park Avenue hand in hand. Christmas decorations, bright lights A good mood prevails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to tell me your surprise, or do I have to get physical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, that is the last thing I'd want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only thought that if you're serious about this around-the-world nonsense. It might be handy to have a plane to fly in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except it would have to be an Electra, and they cost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...$36,000. After a generous discount from Lockheed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May as well be a billion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not to mention at least another 36 to get it modified and ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances at him.      He looks awfully smug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your surprise is, you robbed a bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually.    A university.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop.    What on earth...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've sort of persuaded Ed Elliot to create an Amelia Earhart Fund for Aeronautical Research at Purdue. And suggested a budget item of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...oh, eighty grand. For a suitable `flying laboratory.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes just bug out.      No!   He nods, slowly.   Uh-h she... ...THROWS her arms around his neck, KISSING him hard enou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to startle passersby. It only makes him chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said, I've sort of persuaded Ed. There are a bunch of trustees and donors, tho. We have to get them on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I could help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way. That's not the surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not?    Uh-uh.   And he glances to... ...the window of the GALLERY they've stopped at. She sees magnificently carved CHEST. On a crest in the front: AE. We PAN the surface, to see planes, oceans, a shamrock for Londonderry landing, dozens more symbols of her triumphs, in a bottom corner, looking up at all of this in wonder.. ...a small cat.     In a long frock coat. GEORGE (a whisper) Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her tears just come. She's standing on Park Avenue and sh can't do anything about it. He reaches a tender hand... ...and strokes her hair.      He is her hero.   See it in eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't wait to see what you got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sniffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat food.    A whole case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 Amelia at her writing desk.       Determined, focused. to write...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Mr. President: Some time ago I told you and Mrs. Roosevelt about my confidential plans for a world flight. The chief problem is the jump westward from Honolulu...

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: s she writes, DISSOLVE TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glittering table surrounded by high rollers. George and President Elliot sit on either side of Amelia, who has ri to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As President Elliot has said, it would be a shining adventure, beckoning with new experiences. Making me more useful to the program here at Purdue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks into the eyes of each in turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is much more. I believe that women should do for themselves what men have done - and occasionally what men have not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This might encourage other women toward greater independence of thought and action. And I know how deeply you gentlemen desire that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is gentle laughter.   Amelia reacts in mock surpris

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, of course, from my chats earlier in the evening. With each of your wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter.   Applause from a wife, then the others, t all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that spirit, I want each of you to reach for your checkbooks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards their amusement.   And losing none of the war of her own smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that quite literally. This is an opportunity for me to exhibit the quality my husband admires most.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: eorge and Amelia gaze at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The capacity. To be relentless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LOCKHEED ELECTRA, a sleek state-of-the-art aircraft w its gleaming metallic surface, nose up in the center of a huge space. Its engines are on hoists, being worked on by team of MECHANICS. Eight-year-old Gore gazes up, as if he has never seen anything quite so wondrous. Amelia and Gene watch, with barely suppressed smiles. He's in a suit. She's in grease stained overalls from working with the mechanics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'd be the first one, right? ou always like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To fly around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's Magellan, 400 years go. Actually, he didn't make it. And he died. And he used a boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's almost the same, except it's completely different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glowers at her.    She glowers back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are men who say they flew around the world, but they didn't ly around all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because at higher latitudes, it's short trip. At the North Pole, ou just spin in a circle and you've gone around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why are you asking? Just to show how smart you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's grinning.       She just glowers harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way to really fly around he world is to fly the entire circumference of 27,000 miles. Like at the equator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's tried it.    You think I should?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dare me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she serious?       She seems to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask her about the Pacific. The maximum range of the Electra is 4000 miles. And the closest land est of Honolulu is farther than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore looks to her.       Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to refuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the air. One plane to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy is staring at her now.       Staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really going to do all this, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't you think I can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on Gene.   He smiles at his kid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out to the car and get Sara. Ask if she'll take you for an ice cream. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy knows he's being dismissed. Looks from his dad to Amelia, who steps forward to give him a hug and a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll play some cards before you leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then. He waves. One more glance at dad, and Gore goes. Gene gestures for Amelia to come with him, away fro the mechanics. What's up? But he's already walking to... ...a little folding table, off in a corner.     She follo Sits. Well...?       G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't refuel in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: s that an opinion or an order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His rueful smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only good thing about losing our former relationship is I feel a little freer to tell you when you're being completely crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I bet there are more advantages than just that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's backing down on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a good enough pilot to o mid-air refueling. You will not be able to control the Electra or that docking maneuver for that amount of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've taken bigger risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've noticed. Don't be so proud of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into a pocket. Pulls out a folded sheet of pap It opens to reveal a MAP of the Pacific. A dot is CIRCLED red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Howland Island. It's half- way between Honolulu and New Guinea. It has no elevation, no trees, it's a mile wide and a mile and a half long. Hardly anyone knows or cares that it exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your vacation home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're colonizing it, because when the Japanese make their move, we're going to need a refueling strip there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blinks.   The Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try reading the newspapers between he lines. We haven't started building the runways yet. Maybe if someone I knew could get the President's attention...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at the map.   The dot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really tiny, a grain of sand n the middle of a thousand miles f nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are clicking through a calculus of their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F You'd need a first-class navigator or that leg. Which means the trip can't be entirely solo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And softly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you handle that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.       He waits without saying a word. AMELIA (softly back) Don't rush me. I'm thinking.

dialogues.text: A Coast Guard station overlooking the Pacific. A lone wom leans on a railing. From the station, a MAN emerges, he has... ...a thermos and two large mugs. He pours steaming coffee into each, and brings them to the woman at the rail. She turned to study him as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hullo, Fred. It's good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds out her hand. He juggles the mugs, so he can sh it. Strong look in each other's eyes. Hands her a mug...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you like your coffee black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time of day, I like it with bacon and eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His slight grin.       A handsome guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over easy on the eggs.      Your job could depend on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence between them.       Comfortable smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we sizing me up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, of course, this is exactly what she's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm told that mid-air refueling would be beyond my abilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe not. 20% it works. 0% you crash. 60% you don't get he fuel, so you're cooked anyway.

dialogues.text: E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better odds of hitting that island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel about 100%?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching his eyes as he says that.    Evaluating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even with cloud cover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've crossed the Pacific by air 18 times. Pan Am told you I'm the best celestial navigator they've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone else told you I have a drinking problem. Which is a big art of why we're here, yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pan Am will tell you. Everyone I ver worked for will tell you. Nothing's interfered with my performance. Not once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad drank. He lied all the time. Rest his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trusted Bill Stultz. That worked out. Rest his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill just had to find Europe. We're looking for something less than two miles long, with nothing higher on it than 18 feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you're looking for. I'm looking for coordinates on a map. And if it doesn't work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spreads his large hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money-back guarantee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds the look. AMELIA (softly) Hey.   How can I lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I pressure the navy to build a landing strip at Howland Island? How exactly would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L         Threaten not to enlist? aughter in the room.   More flashes.

dialogues.text: The airstrip has been planned for a long time. I was thrilled to learn it will be ready in time for my flight. The navy has been wonderful, as always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amelia, what do you say to the charges that your husband is pulling the strings, pressuring you nto this around-the-world flight o make a financial killing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George BOLTS forward to the microphones, looks at his wif with astonishment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, you're flying around the world? Don't you know a woman's place is in the home??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press ROARS with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, why don't you go along this time? Watch over the little woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begged to go. But it seems that between 185 pounds of husband and 1 85 pounds of fuel, I lost out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gazes at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least, I think that's what all he laughter meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a kiss.   Thirty FLASHES record it.   As he back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Experts are saying that this `flying laboratory' is a sham. There's nothing to be learned for aviation, and you're just in this for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place gets really quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I to argue with `experts?' I'll just give you my plain old common-sense thinking on this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pens come up, cameras jockey for position. This is what they're waiting for. She holds up one finger. First...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may not learn much about the plane, but we will about the pilot. Endurance over a month's journey, flying nearly every day. Response o stress, crises. I think that will make a contribution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holds up a second finger.   Two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a working stiff like all of you. I don't apologize for the fact that I need money to live. And to keep financing my flying, which is what I love. I think that's a positive example for women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third finger.   Three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing this as a scientist. I'm a flyer, boys, pursuing my passion. For the fun of it. The fun of it. Something I recommend as a healthy motive for women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wink.   A shrug...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and maybe even some men.

dialogues.text: The Electra ready to go in first light, engines humming. Amelia walking alone toward the plane. SUPERIMPOSE:   LUKE FIELD, HONOLULU.   MARCH 20, 1937. he waves goodbye to crew and press. Climbs the steps to b welcomed by Fred's hand gently pulling her aboard. The do CLOSES. We see Amelia and Fred in the cockpit. He checks gauge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely. We've got so much fuel we can't possibly get off the ground. Much safer than flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we need enough for a third pass at Howland. After you miss it the first couple times around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he runway lights go ON, and...

dialogues.text: 83 Amelia THROTTLING DOWN the left engine.    The plane SWIN WILDLY to the left, as...

dialogues.text: ...the RIGHT WHEEL COLLAPSES, the plane SPINS TO THE LEFT we INTERCUT between the cockpit and the runway as the Electra... ...CAREENS MADLY for a thousand feet, Amelia CUTTING THE SWITCHES to the engines, fighting for control, PROPELLERS SMASHED by the concrete runway, SPARKS FLYING IN EVERY DIRECTION... INTERCUT. Oakland Airport. George and his retinue waiting A phone RINGING. Someone takes the call, his face freezes . he looks wildly around to... ..George, who's there, SNATCHING the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMASH CUT to the cockpit, the Electra SPINNING crazily on belly, SPARKS EVERYWHERE, the plane suddenly comes... ...to a BONE-JARRING STOP. The right MOTOR is pushed up I its wing, which itself has BUCKLED, the stabilizer BENT, left wing extends UPWARD from scraping the runway, the landing gear no longer exists. SIRENS SCREAM as fire trucks and ambulances race toward t Amelia is ashen, disbelieving. Next to her, a gentle...

dialogues.text: Good reaction, cutting the switch. You saved our ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't even hear, THROWING open the cockpit, WAVING signal they're all right, we SMASH CUT TO...

dialogues.text: 85 George wandering numbly on the airfield, as someone RUNS CRAZY from the office, shouting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO FIRE! NO FIRE, FALSE REPORT! O ONE HURT!
